name: Judas Iscariot
shortDescription: The apostle who betrayed Jesus for thirty pieces of silver, whose death created the vacancy filled by Matthias
longDescription: Judas Iscariot stands as the most infamous figure in Christian history - one of the Twelve Apostles chosen by Jesus himself, who betrayed his master with a kiss for thirty pieces of silver. His name has become synonymous with betrayal and treachery. The Gospels identify him as the keeper of the disciples' money bag and hint at his dishonesty (John 12:6). His deal with the chief priests for thirty silver pieces fulfilled Zechariah 11:12-13. On the night of Jesus's arrest in Gethsemane, Judas identified him to the arresting party with a kiss - a gesture of friendship turned into an act of betrayal. After Jesus's condemnation, Judas was seized with remorse, returned the silver to the priests, and hanged himself (Matthew 27:5). The priests, unable to put 'blood money' in the treasury, used it to buy a potter's field for burying strangers - called Akeldama, the Field of Blood (Matthew 27:7-8). Acts 1:18 gives an alternate account: Judas purchased the field himself, 'and falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out.' Peter quoted Psalm 69:25 ('Let his habitation be desolate') and Psalm 109:8 ('his bishoprick let another take') as prophetic of Judas's fate, leading to Matthias's election. Judas's betrayal enabled the crucifixion while fulfilling prophetic scripture, creating profound theological questions about divine providence, human free will, and the mystery of evil within the community of faith.

biography.earlyLife: Little is known of Judas's background. If 'Iscariot' derives from the town of Kerioth, he was uniquely Judean among the predominantly Galilean disciples. Some scholars suggest 'Iscariot' relates to 'sicarii' (dagger-men), connecting him to zealot movements.
biography.calling: Called by Jesus as one of the Twelve Apostles, entrusted as treasurer of the group

majorEvents.description: Judas was chosen by Jesus as one of the Twelve, sent out with authority to heal and cast out demons
Judas kept the money bag for the disciples, though John notes he was a thief who would steal from it
When Mary anointed Jesus with expensive perfume, Judas objected to the 'waste,' claiming concern for the poor but actually desiring the money
Judas went to the chief priests and offered to betray Jesus, agreeing on thirty pieces of silver
Jesus identified Judas as the betrayer ('He it is, to whom I shall give a sop'). After receiving it, 'Satan entered into him' and Jesus said 'That thou doest, do quickly'
Judas led an armed crowd to Gethsemane and identified Jesus with a kiss, saying 'Hail, master' - the signal for arrest
Seeing Jesus condemned, Judas repented, confessed 'I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood,' and returned the thirty pieces to the priests
Judas threw down the silver in the temple, departed, and hanged himself
Alternative account: Judas purchased a field with the money, fell headlong, and 'burst asunder' - the field called Akeldama

achievements: Chosen by Jesus as one of the Twelve Apostles
Entrusted as treasurer of the apostolic group
biography.legacy: Judas Iscariot is remembered as the archetype of betrayal, his name becoming synonymous with treachery across languages and cultures. Yet his story raises profound theological questions: Was his betrayal predestined by prophecy (Psalm 41:9, Zechariah 11:12-13) or a free choice? Did his role in the crucifixion serve God's salvific purpose? Could his remorse (Matthew 27:3-5) constitute repentance? The Gnostic Gospel of Judas presents an alternative view where Jesus secretly instructed Judas to betray him. His death created the vacancy in the Twelve that Matthias filled, and his fate served Peter's scriptural argument for replacement. Judas remains a cautionary figure about the possibility of evil within the community of faith, the danger of greed, and the tragedy of betrayal.

coreConcepts.name: Betrayal from Within
coreConcepts.description: Judas demonstrates that evil can exist within the closest circle of faith, raising questions about the mystery of iniquity

coreConcepts.name: Prophetic Fulfillment
coreConcepts.description: His actions fulfilled prophecies: Psalm 41:9 (betrayed by friend), Zechariah 11:12-13 (thirty pieces, potter's field), Psalm 109:8 (office given to another)

coreConcepts.name: Son of Perdition
coreConcepts.description: Jesus called Judas 'son of perdition' (John 17:12), the only apostle explicitly said to be 'lost'

coreConcepts.name: Divine Sovereignty and Human Choice
coreConcepts.description: Judas's betrayal raises questions about predestination ('woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed') and free will

coreConcepts.name: Remorse vs. Repentance
coreConcepts.description: Judas 'repented' (Greek: metameletheis, felt regret) but not with salvific repentance (metanoia). His suicide contrasts with Peter's restoration

doctrinalContributions: Example of apostasy from within the apostolic circle
Fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy through his actions
Contrast between worldly remorse and true repentance
Necessity of Matthias's election to restore the Twelve
Warning about dangers of greed and spiritual blindness

jewishConnections.background: Judas was a first-century Judean Jew, possibly from the town of Kerioth
jewishConnections.judeaConnection: If 'Iscariot' means 'man of Kerioth,' Judas was uniquely Judean among Galilean apostles, possibly with different messianic expectations
jewishConnections.zealotTheory: Some scholars connect 'Iscariot' to 'sicarii' (dagger-men), suggesting zealot sympathies that Jesus's non-violent messiahship disappointed
jewishConnections.prophecyFulfillment: His actions fulfilled multiple Jewish scriptures: Psalm 41:9, Zechariah 11:12-13, Psalm 109:8
jewishConnections.thirtyPieces: Thirty silver pieces was the price of a slave (Exodus 21:32) and referenced in Zechariah 11:12

fullDescription: Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve Apostles who betrayed Jesus for thirty pieces of silver with a kiss in the Garden of Gethsemane. His remorse led to suicide, and his death created the vacancy filled by Matthias. The archetype of treachery, his story fulfills multiple Old Testament prophecies and raises profound questions about evil, predestination, and the possibility of apostasy from within the community of faith.
